body_html:
You can look at the implementation of initialized_value to see how to write tf.cond predicated on whether a variable is initialized. I am suspicious of your initialization logic though as it's not safe on distributed. Much better to keep track of the variables you want to reinitialize.
…
On Feb 6, 2018 18:08, "youkaichao" ***@***.***> wrote: @alextp <https://github.com/alextp> but is it efficient? I mean, this has the same amout of work as sess.run(tf.global_variables_initializer()) e.g, if I have a large matrix which is already initialized, this is going to be time-consuming. — You are receiving this because you were mentioned. You can look at the implementation of initialized_value to see how to write

I am suspicious of your initialization logic though as it's not safe on
distributed. Much better to keep track of the variables you want to
reinitialize.
…

body:
You can look at the implementation of initialized_value to see how to write
tf.cond predicated on whether a variable is initialized.

I am suspicious of your initialization logic though as it's not safe on
distributed. Much better to keep track of the variables you want to
reinitialize.

On Feb 6, 2018 18:08, "youkaichao" <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> @alextp <https://github.com/alextp> but is it efficient? I mean, this has
> the same amout of work as sess.run(tf.global_variables_initializer())
>
> e.g, if I have a large matrix which is already initialized, this is going
> to be time-consuming.
>
> —
